page.title: 15CHELTENHAM'S COAT OF ARMS
page.content: {LOCAL HISTORY.}Cheltenham is situated at the foot of the Cotswold Hills in the valley of the River Severn. It is in the county of Gloucestershire and is mentioned in the original Domesday Book. On the town's Coat of Arms an oak tree represents the many{trees}to be found in our streets and parks. The pigeons on the Coat of Arms remind us of how Spa Waters were discovered more than 250 years ago. (A Mr Mason saw{pigeons}drinking from a spring in his field. The spring was mineral water which people thought was good for them. In 1738 his son-in-law Capt Henry Skillicorne dug a well and roofed it. He built a ballroom and billiard room to encourage visitors. { Books}on the Coat of Arms stand for the many good schools and colleges in Cheltenham. Our motto "Salubritas et Eruditio" means Health and Learning.
